revision.text:
An individual's or community's '''religious orientation''' involves [[presumption]]s about the existence and nature of God or gods, religious prescriptions about morality and communal and personal spirituality. Such presumptions involve the study of psychology, ethics, sociology and anthropology.
==Psychology==
According to Whitley and Kite, researchers who were interested in studying the psychological effects of religion on prejudice initially studied the relationship between simple indicators of religiosity such as whether or not a person went to church and the level of prejudice that that person showed. Surprisingly these researchers found that "religious involvement was consistently correlated with a variety of forms of prejudice." (Whitley & Kite, 2010) <ref name=kite>Whitley, B.E. & Kite, M.E. (2010). The psychology of prejudice and discrimination. Belmont, CA. Wadsworth.</ref>
Naturally these findings were not well received by religious leaders or the religious community in general. It was at this point that there was a clear shift in the nature of the research. Instead of being concerned with factors such as church attendance and the quantity of religious involvement, researchers were now interested in the quality of religious involvement. As Whitley and Kite said, "These ideas evolved into the concepts of intrinsic and extrinsic religious orientation." (Whitley & Kite, 2010) <ref name=kite></ref>
==Measuring==
[[Gordon Allport|Allport]] & Ross developed a means of measuring religious orientation. The Extrinsic measures extrinsic religious orientation (1967).<ref>Allport, G. W., & Ross, J. M. (1967). Personal religious orientation and prejudice. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 5, 432-443.</ref> A sample statement from this scale would be “The church is most important as a place to formulate good social relationships” (Whitley & Kite, 2010). This scale brought forth a lot of interest in religious orientations and much research has been done over the years. But as more researchers began studying religious orientation, the more problems that arose with the Intrinsic and Extrinsic scales measuring what they were supposed to be measuring (Hunsberger & Jacson, 2005).<ref name=hunsberger>Hunsberger, B., & Jackson, L. M. (2005). Religion, Meaning, and Prejudice. Journal of Social Issues, 61(4), 807-826.</ref>
==Extrinsic==
Extrinsic Religious Orientation is a method of using religion to achieve non-religious goals, essentially viewing religion as a means to an end.<ref name=batson>{{cite book|last=Batson|first=Daniel|title=Religion and the Individual|year=1982|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=0-19-506208-6}}</ref> It is used by people who go to religious gatherings and claim certain religious ideologies to establish or maintain social networks while minimally adhering to the teachings of the religion. People high in external religious orientation are more likely to conform to social norms and demands rather than what the religion requires, and are often prone to twist religious beliefs to serve their own political goals. Gordon Allport stated that people high in external religious orientation use religion, “to provide security and solace, sociability and distraction, status and self-justification” (Allport &Ross, 1967, p. 434). (Whitley & Kite, 2010)<ref name=kite></ref>
===Prejudice===
Hunsberger & Jackson did a review of studies on religious orientation that had taken place since 1990 (2005).<ref name=hunsberger></ref> Links have been made between prejudice and religious orientation but there have been no agreement on the relationship with intolerance. This is because there are many targets of prejudice, such as race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, and age. Hunsberger and Jackson have found support for the idea that the target of prejudice is important when looking at prejudice and religious orientation relationships. After careful analysis, they have found that extrinsic orientation is positively related to racial/ethnic and gay/lesbian intolerance. People who measure high in extrinsic religious orientation have a utilitarian approach and view religion as a meaningful source of social status. Having high extrinsic religious orientation means you conform to popular trends, such trends including prejudice. The validity of the religious orientation scales have proved debatable, thus relationships to prejudice have either supported or refuted Allport and Ross's theories (Hunsberger & Jackson, 2005).<ref name=hunsberger></ref>
===Example===
An example would be a politician who goes to church in order to gain votes.
==Intrinsic==
According to Whitley and Kite, a person with an Intrinsic Religious Orientation sincerely believes in their religion and all its teachings and attempt to live their lives as their religion preaches that they should (Whitley & Kite, 2010).<ref name=kite></ref> This agrees with what Daniel Batson would say; that while a person with an extrinsic religious orientation sees religion as a means to an end, a person with an intrinsic orientation sees their religion as that end. To them their religion is, "An active directing force, not just a tool used to reach self-serving ends." <ref name=batson></ref> Those with this orientation find their religion to be the most important aspect of their life and seek to contextualize other aspects of their life through their religion.
===Prejudice===
Research has found that people who hold an intrinsic religious orientation sincerely believe in and follow the teachings of their religion. They live their religion, and as a result those, "with a strong internal orientation should be unprejudiced to the extent that their religions teach inter group tolerance." Studies have found that these people show either no correlation or a negative correlation for racial prejudice. On the other hand, these same people often show a positive correlation for prejudice against gays.<ref name=kite></ref> This effect would be predicted, being that while most religions do not speak ill of other races (racism being due to upbringing rather than any Biblical foundation), they do tend to have little regard for homosexuals. {{Citation needed|reason=show evidence the Bible is not racist or tribalist|date=December 2017}}
While this research appears more favorable than the research that showed a correlation between religious activity and prejudice, some researchers are convinced that these people are merely showing what they believe to be a more socially acceptable bias.<ref name=kite></ref> Batson tested this hypothesis by having participants in a study (a study the participants were led to believe was about watching and evaluating a movie) choose whether to sit in a theater with a white confederate, or a black one. There were two conditions in this study, an overt condition in which both theaters were showing the same movie and a covert condition in which each theater was showing a different movie. The researchers believed that a prejudiced person who was attempting to appear unprejudiced would sit with the black confederate when the movie selection was the same in order to appear unprejudiced, but would sit with the white confederate (participants were white) when their choice could be attributed to wanting to watch the different movie. The researchers found that 75% of intrinsically religious participants chose to sit with the black confederate in the overt condition, but only 46% choose to sit with the black confederate in the covert condition. While these results do show that intrinsically motivated people do want to appear racially unbiased, it also shows that they are not racially prejudiced in general. Contrary to the religious orientations theory, extrinsic religiosity was unrelated to prejudice in either condition.<ref name=kite></ref>
===Example===
An example would be a person who truly believes in their religion and uses this belief to guide them in all other aspects of their life.
==Quest orientation==
A third religious orientation proposed by Batson is the quest orientation. People with this orientation treats their religion not as a means or an end, but a search for truth. As Batson said, "An individual who approaches religion in this way recognizes that he or she does not know, and probably never will know, the final truth about such matters. Still the questions are deemed important, and however tentative and subject to changes, answers are sought."<ref name=batson></ref>
===Prejudice===
Intuitively, it is logical to assume that people who hold a quest orientation would be low in prejudice because by having this orientation they have already shown that they are open-minded and willing to change. This idea was tested alongside the intrinsic and extrinsic orientations by Batson in his theater experiment (described above in the "Intrinsic Religious Orientation and Prejudice" section). People who scored high in quest orientation choose to sit with the black confederate about half the time in both the overt and covert conditions, indicating both a lack of prejudice and a lack of the attempt to appear unprejudiced. To summarize Whitley and Kite as well as Batson, quest orientation appears to be the source of "universal love and compassion" that has long been sought by both religious scholars and researchers interested in the psychology of religion.<ref name=kite></ref><ref name=batson></ref>
===Example===
Examples of people who have attained a quest orientation are [[Gautama Buddha]], [[Malcolm X]], and [[Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi]].<ref name=batson></ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Psychology}}
{{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Daniel Batson]] *[[Gordon Allport]] *[[Locus of control]] *[[Racism]] *[[Stereotype]] *[[Prejudice]] *[[Psychology of religion]] }}
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Extrinsic Religious Orientation}} [[Category:Sociology of religion]]

revision.text:
'''Johann Rudolf Julius Steck''' (January 18, 1842 - November 30, 1924) was a Swiss reformed [[Theology|theologian]] and writer.
Steck was a pastor of the [[Reformed Church, Dresden]] (1867-1881). From 1881 to 1921 he was Professor of Theology at the [[University of Bern]]. He was influenced by the writings of [[Bruno Bauer]] and was a proponent of the [[Christ myth theory]].<ref>O'Neill, J. C. (1991). ''The Bibleś Authority: A Portrait Gallery of Thinkers from Lessing to Bultmann''. Clark. p. 164</ref><ref>Smart, Ninian. (1985). ''Nineteenth-Century Religious Thought in the West: Volume III''. Cambridge University Press. p. 169. {{ISBN|0-521-30114-9}}</ref> He believed that the [[Pauline epistles]] were a case of second century [[pseudepigrapha]].<ref>Chalamet, Christophe. (2005). ''Dialectical Theologians: Wilhelm Herrmann, Karl Barth and Rudolf Bultmann''. Theologische Verlag Zürich. p. 23. {{ISBN|3-290-17324-0}}</ref>
Steck argued that the Pauline letters were written by a school of people.<ref>[[Ernest DeWitt Burton|Burton, Ernest DeWitt]]. (1988 edition). ''A Critical and Exegetical Commentary on the Epistle to the Galatians''. T & T Clark International. p. 70. {{ISBN|0-567-05029-7}} "Rudolf Steck, in ''Der Galaterbrief nach seiner Echtheit untersucht'', Berlin, 1888, maintains the historicity of the apostle Paul, but holds that like Jesus he wrote nothing. The four principal letters ascribed to Paul he maintains to have been written in the order: Romans, I Corinthians, 2 Corinthians, Galatians, by the Pauline School, the last being based upon the earlier ones."</ref><ref>[[Michael Prior (theologian)|Prior, Michael]]. (1995). ''Jesus the Liberator: Nazareth Liberation Theology (Luke 4.16-30)''. Sheffield Academic Press. p. 42. "Rudolf Steck declared Loman to be correct. 'We shall have to get used to the idea that no Apostle wrote anything, any more than Jesus himself did.' The Pauline Letters were written by a school. He concluded that the report in Acts is the fundamental datum for the historical situation."</ref>
==Selected publications==
*''Der Galaterbrief nach seiner Echtheit untersucht nebst kritischen Bemerkungen zu den Paulinischen Hauptbriefen'' (1888) [Inquiry into the Genuineness of the Galatians Epistle, and Critical Remarks on the Chief Paulines]
==See also==
*[[Radical criticism]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: /* In Mythology */clean up, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: However → However, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Sharvara''' ('''Dog of Yama''') (शर्वर) is an ancient Hindu mythical dog belonging to [[Yama]]. It is one of the two dogs that guard the netherworld. Sharvara is identified with the constellation [[Canis Major]], the other dog with [[Canis Minor]], together they guard the gates of the netherworld, known as [[Pitru Paksha|pitriloka]] or vaivasvataloka, which is the domain of Yama.<ref>{{Cite book|last=[[Bal Gangadhar Tilak|Tilak]]|first=[[Bal Gangadhar Tilak|Bal Gangadhar]]|title=[[The Orion (Book)|The Orion, or, Researches into the Antiquity of the Vedas]]|year=1893|publisher=Mrs. Radhabai Atmaram Sagoon|location=Pune|page=42}}</ref>
==Etymology== The word ''sharvara'' means variegated or spotted.<ref>{{harvnb|Tilak|1893|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=3S3CBNUD4ggC&pg=PA108 108]}}</ref> In older Sanskrit, शर्वर is written as कर्वर (karvara).<ref>[[Monier Williams Dictionary]]</ref>
==In Mythology == Sharvara can be compared with the Greek [[Cerberus]], the mythological dog of the Greeks with similar characteristics. However, there is no description of Cerberus having a companion, and he is usually depicted with three heads.<ref>[[Apollodorus of Athens|Apolodorus]] and others indicate that he had three heads, but [[Hesiod]] with poetical hyperbole gives him fifty. {{Cite book|author=Elton, Charles Abraham|year=1812|title=Hesiod, translated from the Greek into English verse, with a Preliminary Dissertation on the Writings, Life, and Æra of Hesiod|publisher=Lackington, Allen and Company|location=London|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=hAMyAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA267 267]}}</ref> Scholars have concluded that the three heads were a Greek addition to the underlying Indo-Aryan myth.<ref>{{harvnb|Elton|1812|page=267}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|author=Bryant, Jacob|year=1809|title=A new system: or, An analysis of antient mythology|edition=3rd|publisher=J. Walker|volume=2|pages=[http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=wu.89065067670;view=image;q1=Cerberus;start=1;size=100;page=root;seq=132;num=118 118–119]|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015010301169}}</ref>
Shavara can also be compared to Odin's wolves in Norse mythology.<ref>Geri and Freki, "Greedy" and "Voracious" {{Cite book|author=Bloomfield, Maurice|year=1905|title=Cerberus, the Dog of Hades: The History of an Idea|publisher=Open Court Publishing|pages=https://books.google.com/books?id=W79ZAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA26 26–27}}</ref> Odin (the all-father) just like Yama (the progenitor of all humans) sits on a chair guarded by two dogs.<ref>{{harvnb|Bloomfield|1905|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=W79ZAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA27 27]}}</ref> Although, Odin (Woden), the hunter, the wanderer, god of storm and winter, is more comparable to the Vedic [[Rudra]].<ref>{{harvnb|Tilak|1893|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=3S3CBNUD4ggC&pg=PA138 138–140]}}</ref>
[[Bal Gangadhar Tilak|Tilak]] dates the Vedic antiquity using the assertion that the Milky Way (path of the dead) used to be guarded by Sharvara and a new year started upon the crossing of Milky Way by the sun. Using internal evidence he dated the timeframe of Vedic antiquity (taittriya samhita) to the time when at the vernal equinox the sun rose in the [[Asterism (astronomy)|asterism]] of Orion (Mrigashiras).<ref>{{harvnb|Tilak|1893|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=3S3CBNUD4ggC&pg=PA41 41–60]}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: /* Jalalabad */ On July 1, 2018, at least 10 Sikhs were killed in a targeted suicide bombing at the PD1 market.[2][3]
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox ethnic group | group = Afghan Sikhs
ਅਫ਼ਗਾਨਿਸਤਾਨ ਵਿਚ ਸਿੱਖ ਧਰਮ
په افغانستان کې سکهزم | image = [[File:Afghan Sikh.jpg|300px]] | caption = A [[sikh]] shop owner in [[Kabul]], [[Afghanistan]] | population = 8,000 | popplace = [[Jalalabad]], [[Ghazni]], [[Kabul]], [[Kandahar]] | langs = [[Pashto language|Pashto]] (native), [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], [[Dari language|Dari]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]] | rels = [[Sikhism]] | related = [[Sikhs]], [[Punjabi people|Punjabis]] }} {{Religion in Afghanistan}} {{Sikhism sidebar}} {{portal|Sikhism}} '''[[Sikhism]]''' in '''[[Afghanistan]]''' is limited to small populations, primarily in major cities, with the largest numbers of Afghan [[Sikh]]s living in [[Jalalabad]], [[Ghazni]], [[Kabul]], and to a lesser extent [[Kandahar]].{{cite web |author=U.S. State Department |title = Afghanistan - International Religious Freedom Report 2007 |publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair |date = |url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90225.htm |accessdate = 2009-07-04}} These Sikhs are Afghan nationals who normally speak native [[Pashto language|Pashto]], but also speak [[Dari (Persian dialect)|Dari]], [[Hindi]] or [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]].Shaista Wahab, Barry Youngerman. [https://books.google.com/books?id=y20MTE0C9kwC&pg=PA18&lpg=PA18&dq=afghan+sikhs+pashto&source=bl&ots=284k8eeeVy&sig=1zpLWmNXYMs3PBhZhKB_JbttRfM&hl=en&ei=mojlTPHxJoz0tgOrgaWxCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFMQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=afghan%20sikhs%20pashto&f=false ''A brief history of Afghanistan''] Infobase Publishing, 2007. {{ISBN|0-8160-5761-3}}, {{ISBN|978-0-8160-5761-0}}. Pg18 Their total population is around 1200 families or 8000 members.[http://www.rfi.fr/actuen/articles/119/article_5843.asp Sikhs struggle for recognition in the Islamic republic], by Tony Cross. November 14, 2009. ==Presence== ===Kabul=== There were over 20,000 Sikhs in Kabul in the 1980s, but after the start of the [[Afghan Civil War (1992–96)|Civil War]] in 1992, most had fled.https://www.thenational.ae/world/asia/afghan-hindus-and-sikhs-celebrate-diwali-without-pomp-and-splendour-amid-fear-1.668735 Seven of Kabul's eight Gurdwaras were destroyed during the civil war. Only [[Gurdwara Karte Parwan]], located in the [[Karte Parwan]] section of Kabul, remains.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sikhfoundation.org/people-events/no-home-for-afghanistan-sikhs/|title=No Home for Afghanistan Sikhs – The Sikh Foundation International|website=www.sikhfoundation.org|access-date=2016-03-08}} They are centered today in Karte Parwan and some parts of the old city. ===Jalalabad=== As of 2001, Jalalabad had 100 Sikh families, totaling around 700 people, who worship at two large [[Gurdwara]]s. Legend states that the older of the Gurudwaras was built to commemorate the visit of [[Guru Nanak Dev]].[http://www.themodernreligion.com/jihad/afghan/sikh.html Sikhs set example for getting along with the Taliban]. By Scott Baldauf, Staff writer of The Christian Science Monitor, 13 April 2001 On July 1, 2018, at least 10 Sikhs were killed in a targeted [[suicide bombing]] at the PD1 market.{{cite news |url=https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/four-killed-jalalabad-explosion |publisher=[[TOLO News|TOLO]] |title=Suicide Attack Targets Sikhs in Jalalabad, 19 Killed |date=July 1, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/07/blast-reported-afghanistan-jalalabad-180701120808551.html |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |title=Deadly blast hits Afghanistan's Jalalabad |date=July 1, 2018 |quote=Ghulam Sanayi Stanekzai, Nangarhar's police chief, said the explosion was caused by a suicide bomber who targeted a vehicle carrying members of the Sikh minority who were travelling to meet the president.}} ===Kandahar=== Kandahar has a remarkably small Sikh community, with only about 15 families living there as of 2002.{{Cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/feature/2002/06/17/focus-hindus-and-sikhs-kandahar|title=Focus on Hindus and Sikhs in Kandahar|website=IRIN|access-date=2016-03-09}} ==History== ===Early history=== Some early [[Khatri]] Sikhs established and maintained colonies in Afghanistan for trading purposes.{{cite book|last=Hew McLeod|first=|title=Sikhism|year=1997|publisher=Penguin Books|location=New York|isbn=0-14-025260-6|page=251}} Later, conflicts between the Sikh [[misl]]s and [[Sikh Empire|empire]] against the Afghan-based [[Durrani Empire]] led to tension. Sikhs also served in the British Empire's military during several operations in Afghanistan in the 19th century. ===Wars=== During the 1980s [[Soviet-Afghan War]], many Afghan Sikhs fled to India, where the Sikh community is well-established; a second, much larger wave followed following the 1992 fall of the [[Democratic Republic of Afghanistan|Najibullah regime]].{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/3138282.stm | work=BBC News | first=Sanjoy | last=Majumder | title=Sikhs struggle in Afghanistan | date=25 September 2003}} Sikh [[gurdwara]]s (temples) throughout the country were destroyed in the Afghan Civil War of the 1990s, leaving only the Gurdwara Karte Parwan in Kabul.{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report_sikhs-hindus-reclaim-kabul-funeral-ground_1006343 |title=Sikhs, Hindus reclaim Kabul funeral ground - World - DNA |publisher=Dnaindia.com |date=2006-01-08 |accessdate=2012-09-01}} Under the [[Taliban]], the Sikhs were a relatively tolerated religious minority, and allowed to practice their religion. However, the Sikh custom of cremation of the dead was prohibited by the Taliban, and cremation grounds vandalized. In addition, Sikhs were required to wear yellow patches or veils to identify themselves.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jun/10/world/la-fg-afghanistan-sikhs-20130611|title=Afghanistan Sikhs, already marginalized, are pushed to the brink|last=Magnier|first=Mark|date=2013-06-10|last2=Baktash|first2=Hashmat|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035|access-date=2016-03-08}} ===Karzai administration=== [[File:Kabul Gurdwara Karte Parwan IMG 0623.JPG|thumb|Interior of [[Gurdwara Karte Parwan]] in Kabul]] By tradition, Sikhs cremate their dead, an act considered sacrilege in Islam.{{cite web|last=Hemming |first=Jon |url=http://www.rawa.org/temp/runews/2007/09/17/sikhs-in-afghan-funeral-demonstration.html |title=Sikhs in Afghan funeral demonstration « RAWA News |publisher=Rawa.org |date= |accessdate=2012-09-01}}{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/south-asia/Afghanistans-Sikhs-feel-alienated-pressured-to-leave/articleshow/47611468.cms|title=Afghanistan's Sikhs feel alienated, pressured to leave|work=The Times of India}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-29062770|title=Why are Afghan Sikhs desperate to flee to the UK?|work=BBC News}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/facing-intolerance-many-sikhs-and-hindus-leave-afghanistan-1421124144|title=Facing Intolerance, Many Sikhs and Hindus Leave Afghanistan|author=Margherita Stancati and Ehsanullah Amiri|date=13 January 2015|work=WSJ}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2014/02/afghanistan-sikhs-face-an-uncertain-future-201422312395677867.html|title=Afghanistan's Sikhs face an uncertain future|author=Ali M Latifi|work=aljazeera.com}} Cremation has become a major issue among Sikh Afghans, as traditional cremation grounds have been appropriated by Muslims, particularly in the [[Qalacha]] area of Kabul, which Sikhs and Hindus had used for over a century. In 2003 Sikhs complained to the Afghan government regarding the loss of cremation grounds, which had forced them to send a woman's body to Pakistan to be cremated, following which the Minister of Religious affairs investigated the issue. Though the grounds were reported as returned to Sikh control in 2006, in 2007 local Muslims allegedly beat Sikhs attempting to cremate a community leader, and the funeral proceeded only with police protection. As of 2010, cremation in Kabul is still reported as being disapproved of by locals.{{cite web|url=http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2010/04/14/sikhs-hindus-celebrate-kabul |title=Sikhs, Hindus celebrate in Kabul |publisher=Pajhwok Afghan News |date=2010-04-14 |accessdate=2012-09-01}} Sikhs in Afghanistan continue to face problems, with the issue of the Sikh custom of cremation figuring prominently. City development also threatens to destroy the Gurudwara Karte Parwan and adjoining shrine to Guru Nanak. In September 2013, Afghan President Hamid Karzai signed a legislative decree, reserving a seat in the [[National Assembly of Afghanistan]] for the Hindu and Sikh minority.{{cite web|url=http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2013/09/04/1-wolesi-jirga-seat-reserved-hindus-sikhs|title=1 Wolesi Jirga seat reserved for Hindus, Sikhs|work=pajhwok.com}} ==Diaspora== Before the 1990s, the Afghan Sikh population was estimated around 50,000.{{cite web|last=Jethra |first=Aashish |url=http://www.sikhnet.com/news/2-sikhs-afghan-poll-fray-want-be-first-elected-non-muslims |title=2 Sikhs in Afghan poll fray, want to be first elected non-Muslims |publisher=SikhNet |date=2010-08-27 |accessdate=2012-09-01}} As of 2013, they are around 800 families of which 300 families live in [[Kabul]].{{cite news|url=http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2013/07/31/hindus-sikhs-warn-leaving-afghanistan |title=Hindus, Sikhs warn of leaving Afghanistan |publisher=Pajhwok Afghan News |date=2013-07-31 |accessdate=2013-09-27}} Sikh leaders in Afghanistan claim that the total number of Sikhs is 3,000. Many Sikh families have chosen to emigrate to other countries including, [[India]], [[North America]], the [[European Union]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[Pakistan]], and other places.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/facing-intolerance-many-sikhs-and-hindus-leave-afghanistan-1421124144|title=Facing Intolerance, Many Sikhs and Hindus Leave Afghanistan|last=Stancati|first=Margherita|last2=Amiri|first2=Ehsanullah|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-03-08}} ===Notable Afghan Sikhs=== *[[Awtar Singh]], member of the [[National Assembly of Afghanistan]]{{cite web|last=Bogos |first=Elissa |url=http://www.sikhnet.com/news/afghanistan-dwindling-sikh-community-struggles-endure-kabul |title=Afghanistan: Dwindling Sikh Community Struggles To Endure In Kabul |publisher=SikhNet |date=2010-01-13 |accessdate=2012-09-01}} *[[Anarkali Kaur Honaryar]], member of the [[Afghan Independent Human Rights Commission]] and 2009 Radio Free Europe Afghanistan "Person of the Year" Apart from these, Jai Singh Fani was 1st Member of Parliament who was elected as Independent candidate and he died prematurely at a young age of 37 years on 25 April 1977. After him Gajinder Singh Safri became the second Sikh MP of Afghanistan and he happened to be Jai Singh Fani's brother in law & he left for U.K. with his family and took political asylum there because of the political unrest in Afghanistan. ==See also== * [[Punjabis in Afghanistan]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2009/05/2009525104759111641.html Al-Jazeera report on Afghan Sikhs] *[http://afghanhindu.wordpress.com/2007/01/13/interviews-in-the-old-city-of-kabul/ Interviews in the Old City of Kabul] *[http://www.deccanherald.com/content/54680/afghan-sikhs-face-threats.html The Afghan Sikhs face new threat]. ''Deccan Herald'', 12 November 2010 *[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2010/jul/06/afghanistan-sikhs-persecution Afghan Sikhs: Forgotten Victims]. ''The Guardian''; 6 July 2010 *[http://religion.info/english/articles/article_196.shtml ''Afghanistan: Sikhs rebuilding gurdwaras'']. Gurinder Randhawa - [[Indo-Asian News Service]] 25 Aug 2005 *[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2001-10-20/delhi/27248325_1_afghan-sikhs-gurdwaras-guru-nanak 300 more Afghan Sikhs flee, India waives visa terms]. ''[[Times of India]]'', Oct 20, 2001. *[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0DE4D8143BF933A15752C0A9649C8B63&pagewanted=all A NATION CHALLENGED: LIFE IN KABUL; Keeping Their Faiths Under Taliban Rule Drew Sikhs and Hindus Together]. Amy Waldman, ''New York Times'', 20 January 2002 *[http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2032514,00.html Pakistan: The Embattled Sikhs in Taliban Territory] {{Asia topic|Sikhism in}} {{Sikhism}} {{Ethnic groups in Afghanistan}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} [[Category:Sikhism in Afghanistan| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Nangarhar Province]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Kandahar Province]] [[Category:Sikhism by country|Afghanistan]]

revision.text:
[[File:VanGogh Bedroom Arles1.jpg|thumb|''[[Bedroom in Arles]]'' (1888), is a visual representation of the simple living conditions under which [[Vincent van Gogh]] lived and worked.|alt= A narrow bedroom with wooden floor, green walls, a large bed to the right, a 2 straw chairs to the left, and a small table, a mirror and a shuttered window on the back wall. Hanging over the bed are several small pictures]] [[File:Carl Spitzweg - Der arme Poet (Neue Pinakothek).jpg|thumb|''The Poor Poet'' by [[Carl Spitzweg]]]] A '''starving artist''' is an [[artist]] who sacrifices material well-being in order to focus on their artwork.Chohan, Usman W. [https://theconversation.com/should-artists-pay-their-taxes-in-art-57669 Should artists pay their taxes in art?] ''The Conversation'' July 16, 2016 They typically live on minimum expenses, either for a lack of business or because all their [[disposable income]] goes toward art projects. Related terms include '''starving actor''' and '''starving musician'''. Some starving artists desire mainstream success but have difficulty due to high [[barriers to entry]] in fields such as the [[visual arts]], the [[film industry]], and [[theatre]]. These artists frequently take temporary positions such as [[waiter]]ing or other [[service industry]] jobs while they focus their attention on "breaking through" in their preferred field. [[The Starving Artists Project]] describes these artists as those who have not yet broken into their careers. Other artists may find enough satisfaction in living as artists to choose [[voluntary poverty]] regardless of their prospects for future financial reward or broad recognition. Virginia Nicholson writes in ''Among the Bohemians: Experiments in Living 1900–1939'':
Fifty years on we may judge that [[Dylan Thomas]]'s poverty was noble, while [[Nina Hamnett]]'s was senseless. But a minor artist with no money goes as hungry as a genius. What drove them to do it? I believe that such people were not only choosing art, they were choosing the life of the artist. Art offered them a different way of living, one that they believed more than compensated for the loss of comfort and respectability.Virginia Nicholson, ''Among the Bohemians: Experiments in Living 1900–1939'', (p. 2); Penguin, 2003.
==Cultural depictions== The starving artist is a typical figure of [[Romanticism]] in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, seen in many paintings and works of [[literature]]. In 1851, [[Henri Murger]] wrote about four starving artists in ''[[Scènes de la Vie de Bohème]]'', the basis for the operas ''[[La bohème]]'' by Puccini and [[La bohème (Leoncavallo)|Leoncavallo]] by Leoncavallo. In 1890, [[Knut Hamsun]]'s novel, ''[[Hunger (Hamsun novel)|Hunger]],'' depicted a period of a starving artist's life. In 1924, [[Franz Kafka]] wrote a short story called ''[[A Hunger Artist]]'' about a man who is world-famous for his public performances of [[fasting]]. ==See also== * [[Bohemianism]] * [[Bohemian style]] * [[Community arts]] * [[The Starving Artists Project]] ==References== [[Category:Artists]] [[Category:Asceticism]] [[Category:Stereotypes]] [[Category:Simple living]]

[[File:골굴사3.jpg|thumbnail|right|Temple stay activity]] '''Temple Stay''' is cultural program in several [[Korean Buddhist temples|South Korean Buddhist temples]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Cerny|first=Branko|title=Temple stay: 48 hours at Sudeoksa Temple|url=http://travel.cnn.com/seoul/visit/temple-stay-48-hours-sudeoksa-temple-936870|accessdate=26 February 2013|newspaper=CNN Travel|date=4 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Garikipati|first=Ram|title=An ‘emotionally richer’ Templestay program|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20141026000107|accessdate=2015-05-14|newspaper=Korea Herald|date=16 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Godwin|first=Nadine|title=Enlightening Seoul tour, temple stay|url=http://www.travelweekly.com/Asia-Travel/Enlightening-Seoul-tour-temple-stay/|accessdate=2015-05-14|newspaper=Travel Weekly|date=31 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=|first=|title=Korea uses Spring Tourism Week to promote domestic travel|url=http://www.arirang.co.kr/News/News_View.asp?nseq=179147|accessdate=2015-05-14|newspaper=Arirang News|date=1 May 2015}}</ref> Temple Stay allows participants to experience the life of Buddhist practitioners and learn the various aspects of Korean Buddhist culture and history through stories told by monks. The temple stay program has been operating since the 2002 World Cup game.
== Origin of Templestay == Templestay is an experiential program in [[Korean Buddhism]] initiated by the [[Jogye Order of Korean Buddhism]] at the onset of the [[2002 World Cup]].<ref>[http://www.hyunbulnews.com/news/articleView.html?idxno=126040 "Templestay, the Ambassador of Korean Buddhism"(Hyundae Bulgyo News)]</ref> During its 1,700 years of history, Korean Buddhism has preserved and passed down Ganhwa Seon practice, a kind of Seon (Zen) meditation. Every year during the retreat seasons of summer and winter, about 2,500 monastics enter a 100-day meditation retreat in one of the 100 temples nationwide.<ref>[http://www.ibulgyo.com/news/articleView.html?idxno=98166 "Ven. Hyangbong"(Hyundae Bulgyo News)]</ref> This is a unique Korean tradition in the sphere of [[Mahayana|Mahayana Buddhism]].
This tradition has influenced the architectural layout of temples and monastic life over the years, and one can attain inner calm and peace of mind and body at any of these temples. In their effort to transform the 2002 World Cup into a cultural opportunity, the Jogye Order of Korean Buddhism decided to open their temple gates during the games and allowed both Koreans and non-Koreans to stay in one of their mountain temples.<ref>[http://www.digitalorganic.net/bbs/board.php?bo_table=oculture&wr_id=10 "Chamsali"(Organic Life: Templestay)]</ref>
As a result, in the 30 days the World Cup lasted (May 31, 2002 to June 30), 1,000 foreigners and 10,000 Koreans experienced the Templestay program.<ref>[http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=101&oid=001&aid=0000189317 "Foreign Press, Paying attention to Templestay"(Yonhap News)]</ref> That was a sizable achievement, but more importantly, Korean Buddhism and the Templestay program became known to the wider world as major international media, including CNN,<ref>[http://travel.cnn.com/seoul/visit/33-beautiful-temples-enlightenment-857401 "Simply stunning: 33 incredible Korean temples"(CNN)]</ref> the New York Times,<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/29/travel/29iht-trkorea.3711483.html?_r=0 "Sampling the lifestyle of a Korean monk - Travel & Dining - International Herald Tribune"(New York Times)]</ref> BBC<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/worldcup2002/hi/other_news/newsid_2016000/2016311.stm "World Cup Diary: Korea"(BBC)]</ref> and NHK,<ref>[http://www.hyunbulnews.com/news/articleView.html?idxno=123297 "Templestay, the Promotion Ambassador of Korea"(Hyundae Bulgyo News)]</ref> paid growing attention and reported feature stories about them.
After the end of the 2002 World Cup, the Jogye Order of Korean Buddhism announced the permanent establishment of the Templestay program on July 2, 2002.<ref>[http://entertain.naver.com/read?oid=001&aid=0000199652 "Permanent Operation of Templestay"(Yonhap News)]</ref> The Order then established the Cultural Corps of Korean Buddhism on July 16, 2004 as an operative body to run the Templestay program.<ref>[http://www.buddhism.or.kr/bbs/board.php?bo_table=news_01_03&wr_id=17808&DNUX=news_01_03&page=89 "News and Notice"(Korean Website of the Jogye Order of Korean Buddhism)]</ref> As the national government promised budget support, the number of temples operating a Templestay program grew from 31 in the first year to 110 in 2015.<ref>[P71, 2015 사찰음식 학술포럼, March 13, 2015, 2Fl. SETEC Seoul, Hosted by the Cultural Corps of Korean Buddhism, (Mr. Hongjun Ahn and Mr. Josun Park, the members of National Parliament Korea)]</ref>
The Templestay program is now recognized as one of the major tourist programs in Korea. In 2009, the [[OECD]] selected the Templestay program as one of the five most successful combinations of culture and tourism.<ref>[http://www.imaeil.com/sub_news/sub_news_view.php?news_id=49267&yy=2009 "Templestay, Receiving Praise from Worldwide"(Maeil News))]</ref> According to statistics issued by the Cultural Corps of Korean Buddhism on May 29, 2011, a total of 700,000 people have experienced Templestay in the decade following 2002 when the program began.<ref>[http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/culture/2011/05/27/0903000000AKR20110527181200005.HTML "The Participants’ Number Reached over 700,000 on the 10th anniversary of Templestay"(Yonhap News)]</ref>
== Basic Templestay Programs ==
=== Temple Compound Tour === {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2016}} In most temples this is the very first item on the schedule for Templestay participants. The aim of this guided tour around the temple for first-time visitors is to get to know the age-old traditions and culture of temples as well as the monastic lifestyle of Buddhist monks and nuns. In this way, participants are shown where the temple dining hall and public restrooms are and so they feel more at home. As they are led through the various buildings and structures of the temple, they discover firsthand the beauty of monastic architecture, paintings, handicrafts and landscaping, and so see many things that they might have otherwise missed. The guide often tells ancient stories behind many of the buildings and art as well as the temple itself.
[[File:국제선센터2.jpg|thumbnail|right|Chamseon]] === Seon Meditation (chamseon) === [[Korean Seon|Seon]] [[Buddhist meditation|meditation]] (chamseon) is similar to other forms of meditation. However, it does differ in one particular respect and that is that chamseon’s goal is to achieve single-minded absorption through the illogical doubt raised by a [[Hua Tuo|hwadu]] (the punch-line to a [[Kōan|koan]]) so that the rambling mind is momentarily quieted. It is one of the most important practices of Korean Buddhism. A chamseon session usually consists of 50 minutes of Seon meditation followed by 10 minutes of slow and fast walking (pohaeng or gyeonghaeng). Depending on the temple and the program, longer or shorter periods of meditation are offered in which participants learn the aim and method as well as correct posture.<ref>[http://www.koreanbuddhism.net/bbs/board.php?bo_table=1040&wr_id=25 "Meditation"(English Website of the Jogye Order of Korean Buddhism)]</ref>
[[File:마곡사2.jpg|thumbnail|right|Conversation over Tea with Monastics]] === Conversation over Tea with Monastics (Chadam) === Sometime in the afternoon or evening, when monastics are not so busy with daily tasks, one of them invites the Templestay participants to drink tea. For monastics, all aspects of the day are a part of Buddhist practice, and drinking tea is considered an important one. This is the time for participants to enjoy a moment with monastics while asking questions about temples or monastic life or even requesting advice about how to live better. Participants may have the opportunity to view the world through the eyes of Buddhist practitioners and even reassess their own lives and improve their well being.<ref>[http://www.visitseoul.net/en/article/article.do?_method=view&m=0005002003001&p=02&art_id=39120&lang=en "Templestay: Finding your true self"(Visit Seoul, The Official Travel Guide to Seoul)]</ref>
[[File:월정사2.jpg|thumbnail|left|Formal Monastic Meal]] === Formal Monastic Meals (Baru Gongyang) === In Korean Buddhism, “gongyang” means “offering.” During a meal one reflects deeply on the countless people and efforts that have brought the food that one receives. In this way, one learns to be grateful for even a single spoonful of rice.
Before the meal, everyone recites a verse which teaches participants how to reflect upon the Buddha’s teachings that are embodied in the act of receiving food. Everyone eats from a set of bowls called “baru” as monastics do, and they are told not to waste a single grain of rice out of respect for the offering.<ref>[http://www.koreanbuddhism.net/bbs/board.php?bo_table=1010&wr_id=95 "Barugongyang"(English Website of the Jogye Order of Korean Buddhism)]</ref>
[[File:약천사4.jpg|thumbnail|right|Buddhist Services]] === Buddhist Ceremonies (Yebul) === In the daily routine of Korean temples, the most important event is the Buddhist ceremony called yebul. This ceremony refers to paying respect to the Buddhas enshrined in the Dharma halls three times a day and repeating the teachings, usually before dawn, 10 a.m., and in the evening. Yebul is also called the “ceremony of five fragrances (obunhyangnye)” because participants reaffirm the five virtues that practitioners hope to perfect. Yebul is the ceremony that regulates the day and is attended by everyone possible in the temple compound.
Different instruments are used to symbolically call all beings to join the ceremony. First of all the large bell is sounded, next the drum calls all animals, then the wooden fish for the water-dwelling animals and finally the cloud-shaped gong for the animals of the air. The ceremony continues with a re-affirmation of the refuge we take in the various Buddhas, [[Bodhisattva|Bodhisattvas]] and generations of Seon Patriarchs. Then follows the recitation of the [[Heart Sutra]] and the Wishes for the welfare of the temple and all people (Barunmoon).<ref>[http://www.koreanbuddhism.net/bbs/board.php?bo_table=4010&wr_id=2&sfl=wr_subject&stx=%EC%98%88%EB%B6%88&sop=or "Yebul, Morning and Evening Buddhist Ceremonies"(English Website of the Jogye Order of Korean Buddhism)]</ref>
[[File:묘각사4.jpg|thumbnail|left|108 Prostrations ]] === 108 Bows (Baekpalbae) === Another major practice of Korean Buddhism is bowing. This practice consists of 3 bows, 108 bows, 1,080 bows or 3,000 bows and aims at ridding the practitioner of greed and attachment. The 108 bows is an act of atonement for one’s recognized ignorance and cravings, and the 108 kinds of afflictions that arise within them. In this respect, the 108 bows symbolize a fresh start as well and so one empties the illusions one has come to believe to make up one’s “self” and earnestly fills the void with new good intentions.<ref>[http://london-zen-centre.weebly.com/bowing-prostrations.html "Bowing, Prostrations"(London Zen Centre)]</ref>
[[File:국제선센터3.jpg|thumbnail|right|Making Lotuses]] === Making Lotuses === {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2016}} In Buddhism, [[Lotus Flower|lotus flowers]] symbolize [[Buddha Nature]], the potential to become [[Enlightenment in Buddhism|enlightened]], which we all possess. Just as lotus flowers are not stained with the mud in which they grow, ignorant sentient beings can reveal their inherent Buddha Nature once awakened.
Korean Buddhism holds the Lotus Lantern Festival every year on the [[Buddha’s Birthday]], which falls on the eighth day of the fourth lunar month. Buddhists handcraft their own lanterns (which are unique to Korean Buddhism), which represent purification and wisdom. The way each petal of thin paper is glued to the paper cup, one by one with great care by Templestay participants, is meant to be a reminder of Buddhists’ fervent wish to persevere in becoming less selfish and more compassionate.
There is also a huge lantern parade through the center of [[Seoul]] and cultural performances until late at night during this national festival.
==Gallery== <center><gallery> file:미황사.jpg file:내소사.jpg file:범어사.jpg file:삼화사 템플스테이.jpg file:마곡사.jpg file:전등사.jpg file:대원사.JPG </gallery></center>
==External links== *{{Official|http://www.templestay.com/}}
